name: Void Linux
description: Void Linux is an independent, general-purpose Linux distribution known for its simplicity, performance, and unique design choices such as using runit instead of systemd and its own package manager, xbps.

sections.title: Early Years
sections.text: Void Linux was created in 2008 by Juan Romero Pardines, a former NetBSD developer. It was developed from scratch, independent of any other major distribution.

sections.title: Growth and Development
sections.text: Void gained attention for its minimalism, fast boot times, and unique design choices, including its own xbps package manager and the adoption of runit as an init system.

sections.title: Current Status
sections.text: Void Linux remains a niche but respected choice among power users. It is maintained by a community of contributors and supports both glibc and musl libc versions.

sections.title: Init System Philosophy
sections.text: Void Linux deliberately avoids systemd, using runit for a simpler, more transparent init system. This appeals to users who want more control over their system startup and services.
